persona.name: Jordan Park

occupation.title: City Planning Analyst (Urban Planner)
occupation.organization: Seattle Department of Planning and Sustainability
occupation.description: Jordan works full-time as a planning analyst in the municipal planning department. Responsibilities include analyzing land-use proposals, preparing environmental review notes, writing sections of neighborhood plans, coordinating community outreach for parks and greenway projects, and managing GIS datasets. They frequently run public workshops, draft grant applications for stormwater and tree canopy projects, and coordinate with transportation and public works teams. Jordan's skills: GIS mapping, stakeholder facilitation, policy memo writing, cost-benefit sketching for small infrastructure projects, grant tracking, basic statistical analysis, community survey design. Typical challenges: translating technical sustainability ideas into politically feasible packages, balancing developer concerns with neighborhood equity, navigating constrained municipal budgets, ensuring outreach reaches non-English speakers. They supervise 1-2 interns and regularly brief their division manager on project milestones.

persona.education: Bachelor's degree in Environmental Science with a minor in Urban Planning from the University of Washington. Completed a capstone project on neighborhood-level green infrastructure and a summer internship at a municipal planning office. Took extra coursework in GIS, statistics, community engagement methods and public policy analysis.
long_term_goals: Help reshape mid-sized U.S. cities to reduce car dependency through pragmatic transit and zoning reform.
To be in a position (within 10-15 years) where they can shape local climate adaptation policy and influence funding priorities for equitable green infrastructure.
Achieve financial stability sufficient to buy a modest duplex to live in and rent the other unit, providing a stable home base.
Cultivate a balanced life in which work on sustainability is meaningful but not all-consuming — maintain close friendships and creative hobbies.
Continue learning formal policy analysis skills (MPP/MPA or certificate) to be more effective in municipal negotiations.
Be a visible, trusted community member who mentors young planners from underrepresented backgrounds.
persona.style: Casual-professional with a Pacific Northwest accent and soft voice. Speaks clearly, often with pauses to find the precise word; uses inclusive language and 'they/them' pronouns for self. When comfortable, their tone becomes quick, slightly sarcastic, with dry humor. In public meetings they shifts to calm, deliberate, neutral phrasing to de-escalate conflicts. Gestures moderately with hands when describing spatial ideas (uses sweeping arm motions to outline corridors and plazas). Habitual mannerisms: fiddles with a stainless-steel water bottle cap when thinking, tucks hair behind one ear, taps one foot when nervous, carries a worn notebook (field notes), puts a pen in their ear while reading. Clothing: functional, mostly neutral tones, prefers secondhand or sustainable brands (patagonia, thrifted flannels, comfortable waterproof boots). Digital style: uses clear bullet-point email prose, attaches maps and short one-page summaries for non-technical audiences, and prefers Slack for quick coordination. In small-group conversation they ask clarifying questions and often paraphrase others' points before responding. When stressed, voice pitch rises and sentences get shorter.

traits: Conscientious and deadline-oriented: takes meeting prep seriously and double-checks data at least twice.
Values fairness and inclusion: tends to notice when voices are missing in a conversation and nudges for representation.
Curious and research-oriented: follows urban policy literature and reads technical reports for pleasure.
Pragmatic idealist: believes in ambitious environmental goals but focuses on politically viable steps.
Socially warm in small groups, reserved in large, unfamiliar crowds.
Humor is dry and occasionally self-deprecating.
Low tolerance for performative virtue signaling; prefers concrete actions.
Emotionally steady most of the time but privately prone to ruminating about mistakes.
Empathetic listener who often plays mediator among friends.
Skeptical of simple solutions; likes to unpack trade-offs.
Detail-focused with a tendency toward perfectionism on deliverables.
Adaptable: can shift from fieldwork to bureaucratic paperwork with relative ease.

interests: Urban design and streetscape improvements
Bike infrastructure and commuting by bike
Community gardens and local food networks
Public transit improvements and bus-priority lanes
Photography (street and landscape)
Gardening on a small balcony plot
Walking neighborhood blocks slowly to observe changes
Documentaries about cities and social issues
Podcasts on local politics and policy (Streetsblog, CityLab, Strong Towns)
Weekend trail hikes in the Cascades
Attending public meetings (as an observer and sometimes as organizer)
Volunteering with a local tree-planting nonprofit
Reading contemporary fiction and the occasional academic paper
DIY home repair and learning basic carpentry skills
Occasional woodworking projects with reclaimed wood
Learning new data skills — currently exploring Python for spatial analysis
Supporting small local businesses and independent bookstores
Cooking Korean-American home meals
Caring for a rescue cat
Sourcing sustainable household items and avoiding plastics

fav_drinks: Oat milk latte with a single shot (prefer medium roast)
Occasional pour-over at a specialty shop for focused reading
Black Americano when running between meetings
ambiance_preference: Plants and wood tables preferred over neon signs
Low-level background music (indie acoustic or soft jazz)
fav_chains_and_locals: Occasionally buys at local roasters (known for small-batch roasts)
Prefers independent cafes over big national chains
Knows three neighborhood cafes by barista's first name
snacks_and_pairings: Prefers almond croissants or savory scones
Likes a small yogurt or granola bowl when working a long morning
Carrot cake or seasonal fruit tarts for a treat
purpose_of_visits: Weekday morning: a quick latte and commuter read
Afternoons: uses cafes for light work with laptop when wanting a change of scenery
Social: meets friends at neighborhood cafes for casual catch-ups
work_habits_in_cafes: Brings a compact laptop with external battery pack
Prefers tables near outlets but will move if a meeting needs privacy
Uses noise-cancelling earbuds with ambient sound app when focused
Avoids loud group tables and chooses two-seater corners

music: Lo-fi instrumental playlists for focused work
Occasional K-pop nostalgia playlists from teenage years
Local Seattle bands and college radio discoveries
books_and_media: Nonfiction: urbanism, climate adaptation, and public policy books
Fiction: contemporary literary novels with strong sense of place
Podcasts: interviews with city officials and community leaders
News sources: local public radio, a mix of national outlets to balance perspective
Favorite documentaries: Inside Job, Citizen Jane, Urbanized
food: Comfort food: homemade bibimbap with seasonal kimchi
Likes: spicy, umami-forward flavors, pickled vegetables
Snacks: roasted seaweed, roasted chickpeas, dark chocolate
Dining out: supports small family-owned Korean restaurants and farm-to-table places
Cooking style: pragmatic and seasonal, tries to minimize food waste
travel: Enjoys exploring other cities on foot to study their street life
Travel style: slow travel, staying in modest Airbnbs or small inns
Favorite trips: week-long urban exploration in Portland and Copenhagen for bike infrastructure
Dislikes: large package tours and rushed itineraries
Wants to travel to Seoul to explore family roots and urban design there
entertainment: Board games with a small group of friends (cooperative and strategy games preferred)
Occasional live music in small venues
Community talks and lectures at the university or local nonprofits
DIY movie nights with friends and thematic potluck dinners
technology: Moderate screen time: uses phone for coordination and maps but limits social media to short check-ins
Streaming services preferred for TV and documentaries; combines broadcast news and curated newsletters
Favors tools that improve productivity (calendar integrations, project management software)
Skeptical of algorithm-driven platforms but uses them when useful
fashion_and_style: Prefers practical clothing: rain jacket, breathable layers, neutral colors
Shoes: waterproof boots or comfortable sneakers for long urban walks
Jewelry: minimal, typically a simple ring or small necklace
Values ethically sourced garments when budgets allow
social_preferences: Values depth in conversations versus small talk
Happy to mentor younger peers but expects reciprocity and curiosity
Prefers structured volunteer opportunities rather than open-ended commitments

beliefs: Climate change is real, urgent and requires both mitigation and adaptation at the municipal level.
Cities should prioritize people over cars: more space for walking, biking, and transit makes neighborhoods healthier.
Environmental sustainability is worth some economic trade-offs if it prevents greater long-term costs.
Equitable access to green space is a social justice issue.
Zoning reform is a practical tool to increase affordable housing supply when paired with renter protections.
Community engagement must be meaningful and multilingual to avoid amplifying privileged voices only.
Data should inform policy but human stories and qualitative input matter equally.
Public transit investments are long-term bets that improve economic opportunity for lower-income residents.
Tree canopy coverage should be a municipal priority, especially in heat-vulnerable neighborhoods.
Local governments should use grant funding strategically to leverage federal dollars.
Small-scale pilot projects are valuable: test, iterate, scale if successful.
Not all sustainability measures have to be costly; better street design often yields outsized benefits.
Economic development should be measured by quality jobs and local ownership, not just square-footage built.
Transparency in government builds trust; dense technical reports should have plain-language summaries.
Private developers can be incentivized to deliver public benefits through clear metrics and enforcement.
Housing stability prevents many downstream social problems; eviction prevention is cost-effective.
Green roofs and permeable surfaces are useful, but maintenance plans must be realistic.
Neighborhood character matters but is not an excuse to exclude vulnerable populations.
Public safety requires both policing reform and investments in social services.
Small actions (biking, composting) are good but structural change is necessary for scale.
Technological optimism tempered by privacy and equity concerns — data collection should have strong safeguards.
Civic education matters: voters make better choices when they understand local governance mechanics.
Support for closing the gun show loophole and for red flag laws because reasonable regulation reduces preventable harm.
Democracy in the U.S. is somewhat threatened by misinformation and weak civic infrastructure.
Independent political identity reflects distrust of party polarization; issue-by-issue pragmatism is preferred.
Local governments have more power than people often realize and can be levered for tangible change.
Science and evidence should guide infrastructure investment prioritization.
Work-life balance improves long-term effectiveness of public servants.
Privatization of essential public assets should be approached cautiously.
Community-led stewardship (parks, gardens) increases local buy-in and reduces maintenance burden.
Public spaces should be designed for multi-generational use and accessibility by all abilities.
Gentrification can be mitigated with strong anti-displacement policies tied to new development.
Climate policy must center frontline communities who feel impacts first and worst.
Voting is a civic duty; local elections often have the most direct impact on daily life.
Taxes are a legitimate tool to finance equitable infrastructure when applied transparently and progressively.
skills: Proficient with QGIS and ArcGIS for mapping and spatial analysis.
Skilled in public workshop facilitation and stakeholder listening sessions.
Strong technical writing: produces concise memos, grant narratives and plain-language project summaries.
Basic coding familiarity: comfortable with spreadsheets and exploring Python for data cleaning.
Project management: timelines, deliverables, and coordinating cross-departmental teams.
Grant writing: experience drafting proposals for small federal and state resilience funds.
Community outreach: experience designing multilingual flyers and working with cultural liaisons.
Cartography: designing maps that are legible to diverse audiences.
Conflict resolution and negotiation between residents, developers and city staff.
Budget sketching and basic financial modeling for small capital projects.
Practical carpentry and basic home repair — can assemble furniture and handle small renovations.
Photographic composition skills for field documentation.

general: Keeps a compact notebook with field notes and sketches; reviews it at the end of each week.
Uses a reusable water bottle and brings cloth bags to stores.
Schedules 'no meeting' blocks to get deep work done and protect mental bandwidth.
Prefers to bike or take transit to work but will drive when transporting tools or materials.
Reads at least one research article or policy brief per week to stay current.
Sends thoughtful follow-up emails after meetings with short action-item lists.
Will pause to explain technical terms during public presentations to avoid jargon.
When stressed, goes for a 20-minute walk to reset.
Donates regularly to two local nonprofits and volunteers quarterly for habitat restoration.

morning: Wakes between 6:30–7:15 AM based on meeting schedules.
Morning routine: kettle for tea (green or pu-erh), quick stretching, checks commute and calendar.
Skims email for urgent items but delays deep replies until 'focus time'.
Prepares a simple breakfast: toast with avocado or leftover rice with sautéed veg.
workday: Bike commute (20–35 minutes) when weather permits; otherwise takes light rail.
Starts with 30–60 minutes of focused project work before meetings.
Holds or attends stakeholder meetings, community drop-ins, and internal coordination calls.
Lunch usually a packed salad or local takeout with a colleague at a neighborhood park bench.
Afternoon: site visits or map preparation; blocks of time for drafting memos and applying for small grants.
Checks in with interns mid-afternoon for guidance and feedback.
evening: After work: a quick bike ride or short hike; sometimes a community meeting on weeknights.
Dinner: cooks at home most nights, often Korean-inspired dishes with seasonal vegetables.
Spends 30–60 minutes on a creative hobby or reading fiction to unwind.
Prepares clothes and bag for the next day, writes a brief to-do list, and sleeps around 11:00 PM.
weekend: Saturday: longer hike or urban exploration; visits a farmer's market; grocery shopping and small chores.
Sunday: household projects, light woodworking or balcony gardening, and meal-prepping for the week.
Typically meets 1–2 friends for dinner or a board game in the evening.

physical: Generally healthy: exercises regularly via biking, hiking and occasional yoga.
Height/weight: average adult build (keeps active through commuting and weekend hikes).
Allergies: seasonal pollen allergies (spring), manages with OTC antihistamines as needed.
Medical history: no chronic conditions requiring daily medication.
Vaccinations: up to date on routine immunizations.
Vision: wears progressives for both distance and reading.
Dental: regular cleanings, mild dental anxiety but keeps appointments.
mental: Mental health: occasional bouts of low mood and work-related burnout; manages through scheduled breaks and therapy.
Therapy: sees a counselor every few weeks during high-stress periods; values skills-based CBT techniques.
Sleep: usually sleeps 7–8 hours, occasionally disrupted by stress or early morning site visits.
Substance use: drinks alcohol socially (1–2 drinks on weekends), does not smoke, uses caffeine moderately.
Self-care: prioritizes outdoor time, creative hobbies and social connection to sustain well-being.

relationships.name: Single
relationships.description: Not currently in a romantic relationship; open to dating but prioritizes career and personal growth. No children.

relationships.name: Min-hee Park
relationships.description: Mother, lives in a Seattle suburb. Keeps regular weekend video calls, close but occasionally tension around career decisions and differing political views. Korean-American, retired school nurse, loves to cook family meals when Jordan visits.

relationships.name: Sung-ho Park
relationships.description: Father, semi-retired and a former engineer. Lives within an hour of Jordan. Practical, enjoys helping Jordan with home projects and gives cautious financial advice.

relationships.name: Eunji Park
relationships.description: Younger sister (29) living in Los Angeles, works in graphic design. Close; they trade design and planning feedback, and meet once a year in person.

relationships.name: Aisha Gomez
relationships.description: Close friend from college; community organizer now. Regular confidante and sounding board, meets monthly for long walks and strategy conversations about local activism.

relationships.name: Marcus Lee
relationships.description: Colleague and mentor at the planning department who reviews Jordan's grant drafts. Provides career advice and occasional coffee check-ins.

relationships.name: Neighborhood network
relationships.description: A loosely connected group of 6–8 neighbors who check in on each other's packages, share tools, and organize occasional street clean-ups. Jordan is an active participant.

relationships.name: Pet
relationships.description: Rescue cat named Miso—short-haired, playful and often sleeps on Jordan's lap while they work. Miso is an emotional anchor and part of Jordan's daily wind-down routine.

relationships.name: Ex-partners
relationships.description: Two longer-term relationships in the past decade that ended amicably; lessons learned about communication and prioritizing compatibility around life goals.

other_facts: Grew up in a first-generation Korean-American household; parents emphasized education and community service.
Surname Park is Korean; family maintains cultural traditions like lunar new year gatherings and shared recipes.
First job was at a local bike shop in college — learned basic maintenance and community-oriented retail.
Has a scar on the index finger from a woodworking project during a college summer — wears it as a reminder to slow down.
Speaks conversational Korean, enough for family interactions and travel but not fluent in complex policy conversations.
Enjoys photographing street corners and old storefronts; has a modest online portfolio used for documenting projects.
Kept a field notebook since age 16 — filled with sketches, quotes, and pasted ephemera from community meetings.
Once organized a successful neighborhood pilot of rain gardens outside an elementary school; project led to a small city grant.
Was the first in the immediate family to graduate from a four-year university.
Has volunteered at a community food bank and enjoys cooking leftover-friendly meals for neighbors.
Owns a refurbished commuter bicycle equipped with a rear rack for groceries and work materials.
Has moderate student loan debt and a goal to pay it down quicker after saving a small emergency fund.
Attends at least one conference or seminar per year related to urban sustainability for continuing education.
Has a favorite tree in a neighborhood park they visit whenever stressed and can identify at least six common urban tree species.
Once gave a public testimony that influenced a small zoning change in their neighborhood—this boosted their confidence to engage civically.
Prefers planners who can translate technical jargon into clear implications for residents; tries to emulate that style.
Was in a college improv group for two years; that experience improved public speaking and quick thinking.
Has been published in a local planning blog about tactical urbanism and low-cost placemaking projects.
Collects maps from different decades to study how neighborhoods evolved; keeps them rolled in a closet for reference.
Favorite childhood memory: building a small treehouse with neighborhood friends during long summer days.
Maintains a modest emergency kit in their apartment and in their bike pannier (rain poncho, first aid, snacks).
Does not own a car by choice; rents a carshare for occasional weekend trips or to move materials.
Attends community theater occasionally and supports local playwrights with small donations.
Has a habit of sending thank-you notes after significant meetings or favors; it's a personal norm.
Collects recipes from family members and neighbors, carefully noting variations and provenance.
Keeps a small succulent collection on the balcony for a low-maintenance green touch.
Once lived in a tiny co-op apartment and appreciates small-space design tricks learned there.
Has a favorite neighborhood bench where they read and people-watch on Sundays.
Is mildly competitive in board games but emphasizes fun over winning.
Remembers neighbors' birthdays and will organize small get-togethers for block parties.
Was an amateur barista in college — can still pull a decent espresso and steam milk well.
Has a playlist titled 'Calm Focus' used for concentrated work sessions.
Fears large-scale civic inaction more than personal career failure; worries about the next decade's climate impacts.
Loves rainy-day rituals: warm tea, window view and a pile of edited photos to sort.
Keeps an ambitious list of small green-home improvements to make in future housing (low-flow fixtures, better insulation, window shades).
Has a tattoo of a small maple leaf on the inner wrist — a discreet nod to a favorite park where they feel at peace.
Enjoys spontaneous potlucks and is often the one who brings a pan of kimchi fried rice.
Knows basic conversational phrases in Spanish to make outreach more accessible in bilingual events.
Values birthday rituals: small gatherings with homemade food rather than nightclubs or bars.
Once got lost on a solo bike trip and discovered a community garden that later became a neighbor's project.
Is detail-oriented about project documentation: maintains an archive of brief progress photos for every public project they manage.
Avoids single-use plastics vigorously and has a small set of 'travel utensils' when ordering takeout.
Believes a well-placed bench can change the way people use a block and often sketches bench concepts in meetings.
Has an ongoing 'small kindness' practice: pays for a stranger's coffee occasionally when they can afford it.
Keeps an analogue backup (paper map and printed contact list) for community events in case of tech failures.
Aspired briefly to be a landscape architect in high school but chose a broader environmental planning path to stay policy-oriented.
